direction.raw_text: ..on Jupiter and Mars.." `LEEDS UNITED FOOTBALL CLUB' written on the side of the stadium. CLOUGH smiles, then puts his foot down. The car accelerates past the turning. The BOYS' smiles fade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you going? Dad? You've missed it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've something else to do first. Won't take long. (singing) (MO RE) (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: :                                                   4 CLO UGH (cont'd) "In other words, hold my hand. In other words, darling kiss me..." The MUSIC continues as the car drives on, turning into the MUSIC of a television program.. 5   INT. TELEVISION STUDIO - DAY - (1974)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Today we welcome Brian Clough as he starts his new job as manager of Leeds United, taking over from Don Revie - the most successful manager in the club's history, under whom Leeds have won everything..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ..not QUITE everything. Not won the European Cup...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...but pretty much everything else. Daunted?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daunted? Not at all, Austin. Looking forward to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The biggest challenge of your life, and you'll be without Peter Taylor, for the first time. Your lifelong professional colleague.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Pete's at Brighton now. He had the opportunity to come with me, but Brighton was his choice. Leeds was mine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A surprising choice, some might say. Because you've been very vocal in your criticism of them over the years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've accused players of dirty tactics, cheating, dissent, foul play. You called Norman Hunter, Norman "Bites yer legs" Hunter, you've said Peter Lorimer falls when no one touches him...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I was right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm curious. Why do you now show such alacrity to joining them after such vituperative criticism of them for so long?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodness, it's going to take me half an hour to explain all those words for a start. Laughter from the camera CREW..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Football is a beautiful game, Austin. It needs to be played beautifully. I think Leeds have sold themselves short... 5A   INT. REVIE'S HOUSE - SAME TIME                              5A CLOUGH's interview continues on a TV in a sitting-room, where it is being watched by Don Revie, sitting in an armchair...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ..they've been champions but they've not been good champions in the sense of wearing the crown well. They've not been loved. But then that's hardly surprising, given the type of operation there's been in place there. 5B   INT. YORKSHIRE TV STUDIOS - DAY                             5B CLOUGH continues...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Football clubs are like families, footballers are sensitive people. I'd like to bring a little warmth into the set-up... (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: :                                                     5B MITCHELL "That type of operation?" I presume you're referring to Don Revie..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am.. 5C   INT. REVIE'S HOUSE - SAME TIME                                   5C REVIE continues to watch the TV...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ..who has long been regarded as a father figure in Leeds. And now you're coming in as the outsider, the enemy even, after all the things you've said in public, coming in and taking ouver as STEPfather. 5D   INT. YORKSHIRE TV - SAME TIME                                    5D MITCHELL looks up at CLOUGH... (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you expect some degree of resentment to this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would accept and expect a strangeness, initially, it's   perfectly normal. But it won't be long   before they realise I'm a fair man.   A kind man. And maybe under me they   can experience what it's like to   be in a happy family, after all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can you be sure they weren't happy with Don all along?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They wouldn't have played football that way if they were happy. 5E   INT. REVIE'S HOUSE - SAME TIME                                5E DON REVIE's eyes burn with indignation. He picks up a telephone, and angrily starts to dial.. 6    EXT. TRAINING FIELD - DAY - (1974)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where have you been, boss? JIMMY GORDON, CLOUGH loyal trainer, his face creased with anxiety..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Directors have been waiting more than an hour. C'mon.. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morning lads! Lovely Yorkshire weather! (gestures shivering) I tell you makes me want to jump on a plane right back to Majorca! CLOUGH laughs. The PLAYERS stare in silence. Squinting in the drizzle. Condensation coming from their mouths. JOHNNY GILES stares. BILLY BREMNER spits and continues talking disrespectfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not much of a welcome, was it? And not so much as a smile from Johnny Giles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're five days late!! And did you really need to say that about Majorca? (beat, changing the subject) You know he was Revie's first choice for getting your job.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who? Johnny Giles? CLOUGH looks over at GILES, who turns away, resumes training....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Was he now? And Bremner?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Club Captain. Don's son and heir. His first born. You're never going to get any love from him. BREMNER, a flint-eyed Scot, stares at CLOUGH..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Great. Here's to happy fucking families. 8   INT. CORRIDOR - ELLAND ROAD - DAY - (1974)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MANAGER'S OFFICE - ELLAND ROAD - DAY - (1974)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The `CALENDER' front title sequence, a Yorkshire TV current affairs program. We're in a TV studio. The presenter is AUSTIN MITCHELL, (40)..
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: HUNTER, LORIMER, GILES, BATES, GRAY, CLARKE, BREMNER, MCQUEEN 7 EXT

dialogue.raw_text: Here they are. The Leeds PLAYERS. Long hair and long faces. Surly. Truculent. Dangerous. Out on the practice pitch. In the rain. Some doing warm-up exercises. Others milling dangerously in groups. Their names on their purple track suits. HUNTER, LORIMER, GILES, BATES, GRAY, CLARKE, BREMNER, MCQUEEN 7    EXT. CAR PARK - ELLAND ROAD - DAY - (1974)                     7 CLOUGH's car pulls up. He and his sons get out. A few waiting press. Cameras. Lights. A few FANS with autograph books.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: leads CLOUGH past the training pitch. CLOUGH looks out.. (CO NTINU ED)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: leads CLOUGH and his BOYS down a corridor, where countless photographs of DON REVIE hang on the walls. Holding silverware. They pass an open door, with a sign outside, `MANAGER. Mr. DON. REVIE.' CLOUGH stops. Looks at the sign. (CO NTINU ED)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: walks into the manager's office. The empty chair. The bare desk. His desk. Don's desk. CLOUGH takes a seat in the chair. Presently, a middle-aged matron, JEAN REID, Don Revie's faithful SECRETARY for 13 years, appears in the doorway..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Any chance of a cup of tea, duck?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're waiting for you. Upstairs. CLOUGH swings his feet on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Directors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For me? Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For the board meeting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let them wait. Now, how about that cup of tea? CLOUGH smiles sweetly, but JEAN stares at CLOUGH. She pointedly doesn't move. CLOUGH lowers his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, I'll go then. Wouldn't want to get off on the wrong foot. CLOUGH walks over to the door. Looks at the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's desk is that, love?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yours, Mr. Clough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not mine. I didn't put it there, did I?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Revie's. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's get rid of it then, shall we? Chairs, too. The whole bloody lot. Think it would be best if there were nothing of his left here. CLOUGH reaches the door..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Were you his secretary?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was. For thirteen happy years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's your name, pet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jean, Sir. Jean Reid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In which case, no offence duck, but there's nothing I want typed on paper from you other than your resignation. She gasps..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you can change the locks on your way out. Don't want the ghost of troubled Don popping in now, do we? Rattling his chains. Scaring my young ones. CLOUGH puts his arms protectively round the BOYS, and leads them out of the door. JEAN REID stares, visibly shaken. 10   INT. BOARDROOM - ELLAND ROAD - DAY - (1974)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come in, Brian. CLOUGH sits down at the head of the table. Rubs his hands together.. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? No one going to offer me a drink? Like an undertakers in here. The DIRECTORS shoot looks at one another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did you do it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The interview. For Yorkshire TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've had a phone-call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not so much a phone-call. Bloody tirade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From Don. They only went and rung him. And ran some of your quotes by him. About how unhappy the players were. What "bad champions". Looking for a response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bloody got one, as well. He's gone berserk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He had it coming. He shouldn't have done that piece in the Mirror should he? Saying he thought I was a daft choice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's entitled to his opinions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'm entitled to mine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'm entitled to MINE. The room falls silent. That got everyone's attention. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hired you to do this job because I think you're the best young manager in the country...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. I'm the best old one, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I also did it under the assumption that you'd be coming here wanting the best for the club. For the city of Leeds. So why do I still get the feeling this is all about you and Don?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course it's just about me and Don. Always has been. But instead of putting frowns on your foreheads, o ye elders of Leeds, in your blazers and brass fucking buttons, it should put big white Colgate smiles on your big white faces, because it means I won't sleep and won't eat until I take whatever that man's achieved and beaten it -- beaten it so I never have to hear the name "Don Fucking Revie" again -- beat it so the only name anyone sings in their Yorkshire ale houses, raising their stinking jars to their stinking mouths, is Brian Clough. Brian Clough uber fucking alles. Understand? The blazers and brass buttons, WHITE-HAIRED ELDERS of Leeds stare at one another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Derby County, second division..

direction.raw_text: Here we go. That's us..! CAPTION: "SIX YEARS EARLIER" PETER TAYLOR, seven years older than CLOUGH, his closest friend, his only true friend, appears breathlessly in the doorway back from a fish and chips run... ..followed by BARBARA, Clough's wife, and the three children..

direction.raw_text: Number six.. ON TV: the BLAZER-WEARING ELDER calls into the microphone..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leeds United!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Against mighty Leeds United..! CLOUGH and TAYLOR cry out in shock..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leeds..!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fucking hell..!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don Revie's Leeds! Top of Division One! Here we bloody come! (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you say to that, Mr. Chairman? 13   INT. SAM LONGSON'S HOUSE - NIGHT - (1968)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can hear the cash registers now!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Happy days, Sir. Happy days.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not wrong, Brian. Take the family out for a meal. Go to The Mumtaz. Tell `em I'm paying. 14   INT. CLOUGH'S HOUSE - NIGHT - (1968)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Put the fish and chips in the bin. Tonight's on Uncle Sam. We're going posh. Chicken fucking bhuna in town. General excitement. Everyone starts putting on their coats. 15   EXT. BASEBALL GROUND - DERBY - DAY - (1968)
direction.name: direction

result.heading: MANNY CUSSINS, SAM BOLTON, BOB ROBERTS, SYDNEY SIMON, PERCY WOODWARD

dialogue.raw_text: Half-a-dozen white-haired patriarchs sit at a large table. Matching blazers and matching brass. MANNY CUSSINS, SAM BOLTON, BOB ROBERTS, SYDNEY SIMON, PERCY WOODWARD. Aldermen and Rotary club members. Masons and businessmen. CLOUGH enters the boardroom. Indicates to JIMMY GORDON to look after the BOYS outside. Inside: matching curtains and carpets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The telephone rings. CLOUGH picks it up..
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's right. It's SAM LONGSON, Chairman of Derby County, (60's) looks like Krushchev, cue-ball head, voice like a power-drill, a tough haulage millionaire..
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: stands with two men in overalls, indicating a fading `Visitors' sign...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right, you two, I want Billy Bremner and Johnny Giles to be able to read
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... (indicates door-frames) And this woodwork has seen better days..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BASEBALL GROUND - DERBY - DAY - (1968)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: `Crash', the following morning, CLOUGH bursts through swing doors, and into corridors with the CLEANERS... (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: :                                                   16 CLOUGH Spick and span, understand? Wash these walls down. Give the floors a proper polish. 17   EXT. PITCH - BASEBALL GROUND - DAY - (1968)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want it perfect. Like a fucking carpet. We've got proper footballers coming. Who know how to keep the ball on the deck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you can't fucking train on it then. 18   EXT. PITCH - PUBLIC PARK - DERBY - DAY - (1968)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: inspects the pitch with the HEAD GROUNDSMAN..
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Derby PLAYERS train on a football pitch in a public park. CLOUGH turns to TAYLOR..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know he'll be making a file on us. A dossier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don Revie. Prepares a file on every game. Leaves nothing to chance. Knows every opponents formations. Strategies. Everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've heard he's a superstitious twat. (calling out) Ey..! Help him, someone HELP him..!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We grew up just a few streets apart, you know. In Middlesborough, close to Ayrsome Park. He'll have known my street, Valley Road - probably bought sweets from Garnetts Factory, where my dad worked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heard he wears the same suit to every game. His "lucky blue suit". (MO RE)                         (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he doesn't care for ornamental birds. C'mon, who's covering him...! (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The best manager in the country, Don Revie. Played for Sunderland, like me, as a centre-forward, like me, and England, like me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon, give it and go!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peas in a pod, me and Don. Two peas in a fucking pod. 19   INT. CORRIDOR - BASEBALL GROUND - DAY - (1968)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in early. Before anyone. In shirtsleeves, sweeping corridors. Straightens photos on the wall. 20   INT. ANOTHER CORRIDOR - BASEBALL GROUND - DAY - (1968)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: polishing the sign, `VISITORS' on the dressing-room door. 21   INT. BATHROOMS - BASEBALL GROUND - DAY - (1968)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on his knees, scrubbing, cleaning baths in the visiting team's washrooms. 22   INT. MANAGER'S OFFICE - BASEBALL GROUND - DAY - (1968)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: puts on his suit. Ties his tie. He takes a bottle of vintage red wine from a cupboard. He places the bottles on his desk. Then puts two cut crystal glasses on his desk. His and Don's. A flicker of jealousy on PETER TAYLOR's face, almost like a wife - hurt that his friend is making such an effort for someone else. A knock on the door. JIMMY GORDON appears in the doorway..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're here! (a confused look) Well, almost..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CAR PARK - BASEBALL GROUND - DAY - (1968)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: rushes out of the doors, straightening his cuffs, straightening his hair, buttoning his jacket. First out to greet the arriving team. He turns the corner to see the LEEDS COACH a hundred yards down the street, the PLAYERS getting off the coach and walking towards him..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are they doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They've run out of petrol.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it's that superstition, isn't it? Every away cup ties, Revie makes them walk the last hundred yards. TAYLOR mutters under his breath, "Soppy twat". CLOUGH cranes his neck. Watches DON REVIE, 40's. Thick-set. Severe, forbidding, intimidating, in a huddle with his coaching staff, Les Cocker and Syd Owen. His henchmen. His assassins. His "Goodfellas". His right and left hand. CLOUGH walks towards him. Hand outstretched..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Welcome to Derby, Don. Pleasure to meet you. I'm Brian Clough. But REVIE walks past without shaking hands, without talking, without even breaking stride.. ..and disappears into the stadium, deep in conversation with Les Cocker and Syd Owen. CLOUGH stares. Hand still outstretched. He looks over at PETER TAYLOR, who can't help smiling, `Forget it'. TAYLOR and JIMMY GORDON walk off, but CLOUGH still stares at REVIE in disbelief. 24   EXT. DUG-OUT - TOUCHLINE - BASEBALL GROUND - DAY - (1968) 24 The LEEDS PLAYERS run out onto the pitch: HUNTER, MADELY, BREMNER, GILES, REANEY, JONES, in a line, waving to the crowd, turning North, South, East, West... (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: aA 24   CON TINUE D:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : (3)                                              24 "Beeeep", the REF's whistle blows. A Derby PLAYER rolls in agony, cries out, a terrible, cynical challenge. Horrified, JIMMY GORDON and PETER TAYLOR up on thier feet in protest..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Referee..! CLOUGH looks over to REVIE's bench. Sees REVIE and SYD OWEN quietly applauding the Leeds PLAYER. Encouraging more of the same. As the Derby PLAYER is stretchered off.. Presently, RRROOOOAAAARRRRR goes up. Goal Leeds. REVIE and his henchmen get to their feet. Applauding. 1-0. TAYLOR and JIMMY GORDON immediately start shouting out encouragement to the Derby PLAYERS, new instructions, as the game restarts..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon, keep your shape! Close him down!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Think, Alan! To feet!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now sent it out wide! CLOUGH doesn't join in. He continues to stare at REVIE in his dugout. Suddenly: "Beeep!", whistle! Penatly Leeds! CLOUGH leaps off the bench in outrage. Screaming, on his feel, protesting in disbelief..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? He didn't fucking touch him! Ref! He DIVED! He fucking dived! REVIE shaking hands with his COLLEAGUES. Smiling amongst themselves. Congratulating themselves. Celebrating. The inevitable roar as Leeds convert, followed by, "Beeeeeep", the sound of the final WHISTLE. CLOUGH stares in disbelief. Robbed. Deflated. The REFEREE blows the whistle for the end of the game. CLOUGH watches as REVIE and SYD OWEN brush past, shaking PETER TAYLOR and JIMMY GORDON's hands, (assuming TAYLOR's the manager), on their way to the dressing-rooms, their minds already on their next game... CLOUGH stares as they go..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: aA 25   INT. MANAGER'S OFFICE - DERBY - LATE AFTERNOON - (1968)    25 The two empty glasses waiting on the table. CAPTION: "DERBY 0 - LEEDS 2" (CO NTINU ED) 16A 25   CON TINUE D:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't say good-bye. Or pay me the respect of staying for a drink. Couldn't wait to get away. Through the front door we see: DON REVIE, SYD OWEN and LES COCKER walking to their bus, chuckling to themselves, deep in discussion, already thinking about the next match.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bloody cheats and all. Neither of those goals should have been allowed. But CLOUGH doesn't hear...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just going to have to beat them, Pete. Beat him it's the last thing I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We need to get into the same division first. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We need someone with a good head. Experience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. Our lot were like headless chickens out there today. CLOUGH turns to TAYLOR...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First thing Monday morning, I want you to go and find me that player. A wise head. TAYLOR opens his mouth, is about to protest..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And don't worry about the money. That's my problem. Just you go and find him. CLOUGH's face: watching the Leeds PLAYERS board the bus...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 26   INT. MANAGER'S OFFICE - ELLAND ROAD - DAY - (1974)                 26 CLOUGH's face: staring out at the Leeds PLAYERS waiting on the training pitch. A deep breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right. Better go and make myself known. CLOUGH removes his jacket. JIMMY GORDON and CLOUGH's SONS watch as he walks out onto the training pitch... 27   EXT. TRAINING PITCH - FOLLOWING DAY - (1974)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, gentlemen, gather around, please. The players truculently gather round. CLOUGH watches them, notes their mood, then..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I might as well tell you now. (MO RE)                             (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You lot may all be internationals and have won all the domestic honours there are to win under Don Revie, but as far as I'm concerned, the first thing you can do for me is to chuck all your medals and all your caps and all your pots and all your pans into the biggest fucking dustbin you can find because you've never won any of them fairly. You've done it all by bloody cheating. Silence from the PLAYERS..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. William Bremner. You're the captain. And a good one. But you're no good to the team and you're no good to me if you're suspended. I need you fit for every game, and I want good, clean, attractive football from my captain. Setting an example. CLOUGH turns to PETER LORIMER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Lorimer, I hope you were listening because you're as good a footballer as I've ever seen, but you know how I feel about the way Don let you harangue referees, fall over when you've not been touched, protesting and pointing, trying to get other players booked. We'll have no more of that. CLOUGH turns to JOHNNY GILES..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you, Irishman. God gave you skill, intelligence, and the best passing ability in the game. What God did not give you was six studs to wrap around another player's knee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know what you're talking about. CLOUGH turns to NORMAN HUNTER...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you do, though, "Bites yer Legs". (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People kick me, I kick them back. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not with me as manager. Do that on my watch, you'll be fined and stuck in the reserves. (to all the PLAYERS) Things are going to be a little different around here. Without Don. Might feel a little strange at first. Might pinch a little. Like a new pair of shoes. But if you want your grandchildren to remember you for being something other than the dirty buggers you all were, if you want to be loved as REAL champions, WORTHY champions, you're going to have to work. And improve. And change. (nods to JIMMY GORDON) Now let's start off by playing some seven-a-sides. PLAYERS stare at one another. Bristling. Disbelieving looks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don never did that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm not Don. And from now on I never want to hear that man's name again. Ever. Next player who mentions it, or what he did or didn't bloody do in the good ol' days, will spend a week cleaning my boots. (clapping hands) Seven-a-side. Keep it nice and clean, and sensible. No fifty-fifty's. CLOUGH sees that one side is a man short..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right, I'll play myself. You might learn something, Irishman. Two hundred and fifty-one goals in two hundred and seventy-four starts. CLOUGH skillfully traps the ball between his feet, flips it up onto this head - down onto his chest, then "WHAM" volleys it into a distant goal..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like to see Don fucking Revie do that, eh? CLOUGH removes his track suit trousers, rolls his neck. JIMMY GORDON quickly divides the players into two teams, blows the whistle.. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here, son. To feet. Keep it simple. Think and give. On the deck. Nice and crisp. Yes, to me, Sniffer. To me. CLARKE passes the ball. But it's a fifty-fifty. Another player bears down on CLOUGH..who refuses to pull out.. "CRUNCH", a bone-shaking tackle from "BITES YER LEGS".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Jeeeeeesussss!!! CLOUGH is flattened. Rolls around on the floor. JIMMY GORDON runs up to NORMAN HUNTER..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fucking matter with you? He said no fifty-fifty's. HUNTER aggressively steps forward. Nose to nose. He is immediately flanked by other aggressive Leeds PLAYERS. Crowding the referee. Intimidating him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you going to do about it? Book me? JIMMY GORDON backs off, visibly frightened. CLOUGH lies on the floor. In agony. Holding his knee. 28   INT. CORRIDOR OUTSIDE DRESSING-ROOMS - SAME TIME                  28 CLOUGH listens to the PLAYERS laughing at him. Disrespecting him. His face darkens.

direction.raw_text: "Two hundred and fifty-one goals in two hundred and seventy-four starts." The sound of coarse, cruel laughter among the LEEDS PLAYERS. JIMMY GORDON appears, CLOUGH's two SONS in tow..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got what you were looking for. JIMMY holds up a large parcel wrapped in brown paper. CLOUGH's expression changes. (CO NTINU ED)

direction.raw_text: What about the petrol?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the boot of the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good lad. 29   INT. CORRIDOR - ELLAND ROAD - DAY - (1974)

dialogue.raw_text: rubs his hands in excitement, "Here we go". But CLOUGH is miles away. Still cannot let the insult go. He stares over at the visiting team dug-out.. (CO NTINU ED)

dialogue.raw_text: and his lieutenants. Whispering among themselves. Huddled in thought. Huddled in strategy. Huddled in malevolence. Presently, the game starts. A roar from the crowd. (CO NTINU ED)

dialogue.raw_text: limps down a corridor. In a thunderous mood. Holding the parcel. PEOPLE scatter. 30   INT. MANAGER'S OFFICE - ELLAND ROAD - DAY - (1974)

direction.raw_text: The door flies open. CLOUGH storms into his office. He walks over to the desk. DON REVIE's desk. He unwraps the parcel, and takes out an axe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stand back. CLOUGH's SONS watch as their father violently swings the axe down onto the desk. The sickening sound of splintering wood. 31   EXT. ELLAND ROAD - DAY - (1974)

direction.raw_text: Everything all right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine thank you, Mr. Cussins. CLOUGH smiles politely, then turns, and walks to his car. The DIRECTORS watch..

direction.raw_text: : 22 32   INT. CLOUGH HOUSE - DINING-ROOM - DAY - (1968)               32 "Rrrriiinnnggg", the phone rings. CLOUGH and his FAMILY are having Sunday lunch. BARBARA CLOUGH looks up..

direction.raw_text: Not now, love - please? "Rrrrriinnngggg". The phone rings. CLOUGH tries to ignore it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it might be Pete.

direction.raw_text: (rolls eyes) Of course it's Pete. "Rrrriiinnngggg", CLOUGH tries to eat, then..

direction.raw_text: But it might be important. (to NIGEL) C'mon, eat your carrots. For your Mother. CLOUGH gets up. Walks out of the room.. 33   INT. TAYLOR HOUSE - HALL - DAY - (1968)

direction.raw_text: You asked me to find a player with a good head. Experience. (whispering, furtive) I've found one! He's perfect. Dave Mackay.

direction.raw_text: Dave Mackay?!? He's a hundred and fucking fifty.

direction.raw_text: I admit he's not young.

direction.raw_text: Not young? He's old as fucking time!

direction.raw_text: Well, what did you fucking call me for then?

dialogue.raw_text: similarly in disgrace with his family, similarly unable to go a single Sunday lunch without calling CLOUGH, whispers down the phone, terrified of his wife..

direction.raw_text: You know it's illegal. To sign someone on the sabbath.

direction.raw_text: What? And let Hearts in again in the morning? Fuck off. (producing contracts) I'm not leaving here without a signature. CLOUGH and TAYLOR walk up the garden path..

direction.raw_text: You'd bloody DO that, too - wouldn't you? Come all this way, then just "shake hands"? (shaking head) Dear oh dear. What would you DO without me?

direction.raw_text: Hey, you would never have FOUND him if it weren't for me. CLOUGH stops, rings the doorbell. Looks at TAYLOR.

direction.raw_text: Jehova's Witness, Dave! May the Lord be with you!

direction.raw_text: I remember you now. You had a black eye, a right bloody shiner. (a beat) And never stopped fucking talking! What are you doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come to talk to you about the Promised Land, Dave. Land of Milk and Honey. It's a little place up the M1 called Derby. (a beat) May we come in? 39   EXT. BASEBALL GROUND - PITCH - DAY - (1968)

direction.raw_text: Is he fuck. He's broken more bones than Evel Knievel.

direction.raw_text: Trust me, Mr. Chairman. It's money well spent. LONGSON turns and double-takes....

dialogue.raw_text: ..and into the hall. BARBARA stops. She looks left and right. No sign.

dialogue.raw_text: and TAYLOR emerge from a roadside cafe and walk towards their car. They've missed Sunday lunch. So it's Crisps. Sweets. Fizzy drinks. Almost childlike. Happier in one another's company than with their own families.

direction.raw_text: and TAYLOR watch from the touchline as their new team led by MACKAY plays in a match. CLOUGH watches in admiration... (CO NTINU ED)

direction.raw_text: You're a genius, Pete. Bloody genius. How did you see it? On the training ground: DAVE MACKAY, barrel-chested and older, voice like a bullhorn, is already bossing about the young players, urging them to "think"..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dunno. It was just obvious. McGovern in midfield, Mackay at the back, O'Hare up front. The skewer isn't it? In the shish kebab. CLOUGH watches MACKAY passing the ball, creating space..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's beautiful. A thing of fucking beauty!! CLOUGH grabs TAYLOR's head, kisses him. OVER THIS: we fade in the roar from the crowd... 42   EXT. DUGOUT - CARLISLE - DAY - (1968)

direction.raw_text: "Love and marriage, love and marriage, it's an institute you can't disparage.." To everyone's amusement: CLOUGH sings to PETER TAYLOR, not his own wife..

direction.raw_text: "Try, try, try to separate them, it's an illusion. Try, try, try and you will only come to this conclusion.." In another corner: MACKAY is amiably ribbing LONGSON..

direction.raw_text: ..."the man's crocked", "older than time" "broken more bones than Evel Knievel?"

direction.raw_text: All right, I admit it, I was wrong. LONGSON starts eating his trademark felt hat. Much cheering as he munches in disgust and swallows with difficulty. Suddenly, DAVE MACKAY looks up, sees the television. Calls for quiet!! ON TV: a live awards presentation. From London. DON REVIE is being presented with an award...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ..for Leeds to win the First Division title, and for me to be named as English Manager of the year...feels like a dream come true... CLOUGH watches. His expression changes. His eyes burn into REVIE's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You enjoy it, Don. Go home, put your feet up and fucking enjoy it. There's a good lad. Because we'll be in the First Division next season. And we're going to have you! Loud CHEERS from LONGSON, TAYLOR, MACKAY and CLOUGH. OVER THIS: we fade in the sound of roaring... (CO NTINU ED)

direction.raw_text: Will you be supporting Leeds today, Don?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'd expect nothing less having been their manager for 13 years. But the fact is I'm here today as manager of England...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have any advice to give your successor, Brian Clough, before his first game? A mischievous smile barely perceptible of REVIE's face..

direction.raw_text: Win. The people of Leeds are used to winning. 49   INT. WEMBLEY DRESSING-ROOM - DAY - (1974)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right, the team for today is: Harvey in goal, Reaney, Cherry, Bremner, McQueen, Hunter, Lorimer, Clarke, Jordan, Giles, Gray. CLOUGH folds a piece of paper. A flicker of vulnerability.

direction.raw_text: Obviously all eyes will be on us to see how things have changed. Without Don. What might be different under me. Let's show them some of the things we've been working on. Our changes in attitude, too. Our new outlook. New discipline. New approach. (a beat) Let's see some of you playing with a smile. Team talk over: the PLAYERS put on their shoes. Make final preparations.
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two teams are limbering up in the tunnel. CLOUGH takes his place ahead of BILLY BREMNER.. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course, it goes without saying I'd like you to continue as Club Captain. Silence. BREMNER continues to limber up...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, son, I've nothing but the highest regard for you as a player. They PLAYERS get the instruction to walk out, towards the roar of the crowd...

direction.raw_text: In fact, I wrote you a card saying as much. Did you not get it? From Majorca? The roar of the CROWD grows louder...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Saying how excited I was to be taking this job. How much I thought we could achieve together. And inviting you and your family down to our place in Calla Major any time you like?

direction.raw_text: Never got it. They walk out into the ROAR of the crowd.... 50    EXT. WEMBLEY STADIUM - DAY - (1974)

All around them, (ARCHIVE FOOTAGE) 67,000 belting out "God Save The Queen". But there might as well not be. (CO NTINU ED)

direction.raw_text: (over his shoulder) Because losing wasn't enough, was it? You only had to be the first Englishman to be sent off at Wembley. Our CAMERA widens to reveal BILLY BREMNER pissing in line with NORMAN HUNTER and JOHNNY GILES..

dialogue.raw_text: The Derby Coach arrives. Hydraulic brakes HISSSSSSS. Doors open. Boots, shoes, walk down steps. BRIAN CLOUGH, PETER TAYLOR and the Derby Army disembark. CLOUGH's face: as he looks up at the writing on the side of the stadium. LEEDS UNITED F.C. 60   INT. DRESSING-ROOM - ELLAND ROAD - DAY - (1969)

direction.raw_text: Some PLAYERS getting dressed. CLOUGH, TAYLOR and JIMMY GORDON massaging others. Shin-pads. Water-bottles.

direction.raw_text: Right, last time there was a whole division between you and Leeds. Not now. Not today. Today we're here as Second Division champions, and equals with Leeds. John McGovern and Billy Bremner, EQUALS. Kevin Hector and Johnny Giles, EQUALS. Alan Hinton and Peter Lorimer, John O'Hare and Paul Madely. EQUALS. Now, c'mon, chins up. Chests out. We can take this fucking lot. The PLAYERS clatter out, studs rattling down the tunnel, into the roar of the CROWD.. CAPTION: LEEDS 5 - DERBY 0 61   INT. HOTEL/PUB - DERBY - NIGHT - (1969)

direction.raw_text: ...obviously it's a terrific achievement for Derby, being promoted to the First Division, but the truth is Leeds United have an unfortunate habit of reminding them just how far they still have to go..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arrogant twat..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he's right. Five nothing. They made us look like fools today. And what was John O'Hare doing? Letting Madeley bully him like that. (MO RE)                         (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Push him around. Madeley's half his bloody size. O'Hare needs to toughen up. He's from Scottish dockyards, isn't he? And what about John McGovern? He was useless in the middle. Who's idea was that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was all over the place. Like the Wandering Jew. Giving the ball to anyone BUT his own. We need a ball player, a natural in midfield. Who'll hold onto it. Keep possession. We're giving it away too easily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Someone like Colin Todd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oooh, now you're talking. Lovely pair of feet.

direction.raw_text: I've heard he wants out of Sunderland, too. They're all jumping ship up there. CLOUGH thinks for a moment, then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, go on then. Sign him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? We can't. Longson's already told us. Club's in debt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bollocks to that. I've not brought us all the way to the First Division just to sit there mid-table, and be cannon fodder for sides like Leeds. Sign the man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hang on, hang on, careful...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll handle bloody Longson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TRAINING GROUND - DERBY - DAY - (1972)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A hundred and seventy grand?!? For Colin fucking Todd?!?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Correction, the ALMIGHTY Colin Todd. The best technical footballer in the country.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A salary of three hundred quid a week? You can't pay a footballer that!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the way things are going, Uncle Sam. Football's all about money now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you never to go over my head again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Had no choice. Windows opened up. You were in the bloody West Indies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: WindowS? You mean there were others?!?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Messrs. Gemmell and Hennessy. Two PLAYERS turn and wave to LONGSON..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Afternoon!/Hello!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (eyes popping/apoplectic) For fucks SAKE!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me ask you a question, Uncle Sam. What did you come into football for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To support the football club in MY HOME TOWN. The club I've supported ALL MY LIFE. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm sure we all admire your loyalty...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: the highest rating talk show on TV..
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) You ever see eighty five or perhaps ninety percent of chairmen talking - I'd love a few chairmen on your programme occasionally - I believe the very sight of them brings the game into disrepute (some clap in the audience). And every time they open their mouths it kills it. Because the very thing they've given me a lot of stick about over the years - about talking too much and going on television too much, there are the very people who can put two words together and its rather embarrassing to me that a man - or men - can stop me talking to people like you. I love football. It's deep, it goes right down through. It's in every nerve, vein, you name it. It consumes me. And when I have to come and talk about I like the passions of football to come out. Because there are not enough in the game. (MO RE)                          (CO NTINU ED)

direction.raw_text: `Pop', a WAITER uncorks champagne, pours it into glasses. CLOUGH and his three sheepish new signings: MCGOVERN, O'HARE and DUNCAN MACKENZIE sit uneasily in the bar.

direction.raw_text: Congratulations, lads!! My first signings for Leeds. My Leeds United. Playing with flair and winning with honour. Winning the `right' way. And winning the admiration of fans all over Europe because...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because of the way we play. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because of the way we play!!! MACKENZIE lights a cigarette..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're going all the way, lads. Inter Milan, Barcelona. We're going to win silverware Don Revie could only dream of.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Boss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you, Mr. Mackenzie, you scored twenty-eight goals last season. You'll score me twenty-nine goals this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Mr. Clough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know how many goals I scored before I got injured?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, Mr. Clough. I don't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two hundred and fifty-one. MCGOVERN and O'HARE privately exchange looks, "Here goes".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know how many games it took me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, Mr. Clough, I don't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have a guess. Go on... O'HARE mouths "Two hundred and seventy-four"..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Three hundred? MCGOVERN closes his eyes, "Moron." (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two hundred and seventy-four! Now what do you think about that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that a record, Mr. Clough?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: `Course it's a bloody record. CLOUGH shoots a look to the others..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what ELSE you lot can do that's even more important? You can be my eyes and ears in that dressing room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Mr. Clough/Yes, Boss
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Need to know what they say about me. Who's making trouble. Who the ringleaders are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Mr. Clough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Want you to help me clear this place out. Make it MY team, understand. OUR team. Clean it up and clear it out once and for all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Mr. Clough. CLOUGH indicates MACKENZIE's drink..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now c'mon, drink up. We're off to meet the press.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Mr. Clough. MACKENZIE knocks back his champagne..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Duncan..?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Mr. Clough? (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's "Boss" from now on. There's a good lad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Mr. Clough. CLOUGH sighs and goes. MCGOVERN and O'HARE roll their eyes. MACKENZIE stubs his cigarette, and hurries after them.. 96   EXT. ELLAND ROAD - DAY - (1974)                                   96 "Flash", photographs are being taken by PRESS of the three new signings, DUNCAN MCKENZIE, JOHN O'HARE and JOHN MCGOVERN, all wearing Leeds shirts. PULL BACK TO REVEAL: they are being watched from a distance by several Leeds SENIOR players.. 97   INT. ELLAND ROAD - DAY - (1974)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell did you buy them for? Waste of bloody money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Duncan Mackenzie scored twenty-eight goals last season. John O'Hare and John McGovern are both internationals.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've got two strikers, Alan Clarke and Mick Jones, they're internationals, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And one's injured and the other's fucking suspended.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe if you spent a little more time here on the training ground with us, you wouldn't need to buy Derby "rejects". (a beat) We've a game Saturday. Against Queens Park Rangers. Or had you forgotten? (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I haven't forgotten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you haven't told us a single thing about how QPR will play. Mr Revie would have files and dossiers prepared. Had the reserves playing the Rangers way all week. Had the first team looking out for this and that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bollocks to Mr. Revie! You're professional footballers. Stop Stan Bowles! That's all you need to know about QPR. And I don't have to justify myself to you. Not how or when I conduct training. Not who I buy or pick to play.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Not to us. But come Saturday afternoon, there'll be 40,000 people here who you DO have to justify yourself, to. GILES, BREMNER et al walk off. CLOUGH left, staring. OVER THIS: a large RRRRROOOAAARRRR. GOAL. 98   INT. LEEDS DRESSING-ROOM - DAY - (1974)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry, lads. CLOUGH walks round the dressing-room, shaking hands individually, patting PLAYERS on the back...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were robbed out there today. Broad bloody daylight. That was never a penalty. CLOUGH's tone is sensitive. Tactful. Considerate. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stan Bowles?    Diving like that? Man's a disgrace.. But several of the LEEDS PLAYERS refuse his hand. Or freeze at his touch. Turn away from him..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've spoken to the referee already. Given him a piece of my mind. And come Monday morning, mark my word, I shall be taking this further... The LEEDS PLAYERS stare at one another. Shoot one another looks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyway, I want you all to know, I'm not in the slightest bit critical of your performance today. Not a bit of it. You were terrific out there... (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: spits in contempt. GILES turns and walks out, into the showers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I couldn't ask for more effort. Commitment. (tailing off) Passion. The LEEDS PLAYERS follow. Finally O'HARE and MCGOVERN, too. A deathly silence. CLOUGH is left alone in the dressing-room. OVER THIS: the sound of a ringing telephone. A gruff VOICE answers..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello? 98A   INT. CLOUGH'S ROOM - DRAGONARA HOTEL - NIGHT                  98A It's the middle of the night. CLOUGH speaks into the phone, visibly the worse for wear from alcohol...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must be loving this. Loving every minute. 98B   INT. REVIE'S HOUSE - BEDROOM - NIGHT - (1974)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: walks through a corridor, brushing past JOHNNY GILES, BILLY BREMNER and several other SENIOR PLAYERS. An intimidating atmosphere..
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The LEEDS PLAYERS trudge in, after the game. Angry. Heads hung low. Begin to strip off. CAPTION: "QPR 1, Leeds 0." CLOUGH enters. Visibly gutted by the result, but now's not the time to show it..
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: REVIE's face, half-asleep. Visibly irritated. He sits up in bed. A stout Yorkshire matron wakes beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watching it all fall apart. It's Brian Clough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They won't play for me. Your boys. Your bastard sons. And never will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you drunk, man? It's two in the morning. What do you want? Why are you ringing me here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DRAGONARA HOTEL - NIGHT - (1974)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're loyal to you. Thought you'd like to know that. Loyal to Big Daddy Don..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For God's sake go to sleep. Where's you dignity, man? And don't call here again. "Click", REVIE hangs up. CLOUGH stares at the receiver. 99    OMITTED                                                        99 100   EXT. CAR PARK - BASEBALL GROUND - DAY - (1973)
direction.name: direction

result.heading: HARVEY, REANEY, CHERRY, BREMNER, HUNTER, LORMIER, CLARKE, JORDAN, GILES, GRAY

direction.raw_text: The Leeds Coach arrives at Derby. Hydraulic brakes hissssssss. Doors open. Boots, shoes, walk down steps. DON REVIE, SYD OWEN and the Leeds PLAYERS disembark. HARVEY, REANEY, CHERRY, BREMNER, HUNTER, LORMIER, CLARKE, JORDAN, GILES, GRAY walk towards the Derby dressing-rooms.. 101   INT. BOARDROOM - BASEBALL GROUND - SAME TIME - (1973)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stands by the window, looking out into the car park. He sees the Leeds United PLAYERS. Reads their mood. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their faces. Their focus. Their murderous intent. A flicker of concern on SAM LONGSON's face. He thinks, then calls out to his SECRETARY..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get me today's team sheet, will you? He lets the curtain fall.. 102   INT. CORRIDOR - BASEBALL GROUND - DAY - (1973)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: walks through corridors of Elland Road, carrying the team sheet. Walking towards the dressing-rooms. He turns a corner and runs into CLOUGH..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's up, Uncle Sam? Bit below stairs for you here, isn't it? Taken a wrong turn somewhere?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just seen the team sheet. Hinton, O'Hare, Todd, Mackay. (looks left and right) That's our strongest side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course it's our strongest side. It's Leeds United. Would you prefer I sent out the apprentices?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're at Juventus mid-week. Semi-final of the European Cup. Biggest night in the club's history!! Couldn't you just field...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Y'know...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A weaker side? Am I hearing right? Is the CHAIRMAN of this football club seriously asking his manager to LOSE?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what I mean..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Against their biggest rivals? (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Chairman of this football club is asking his manager to be pragmatic. Manage his resources. Prioritise. We've embarked on a huge program of refurbishment and improvements. New stands. Better floodlights. We need a good run in Europe to pay for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to pretend I didn't hear a word of this. CLOUGH turns to walk away. LONGSON calls after him..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've still got twenty minutes before kick-off. I'd reconsider if I were you. I wouldn't want my employer to be unhappy..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My employer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chairman of Derby County. And Chairman
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: before you ever showed up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right. You were Chairman of Derby County before I came here. I remember that. When Derby County were at the fucking foot of the Second Division, when nobody had heard of them for twenty years and nobody had heard of Sam bloody Longson ever. Full stop. And that's where you'd still fucking be if it wasn't for me; at the foot of the bloody Second Division, where nobody remembered you and nobody had heard of you. There would BE no Derby County without me, no league title, no Champions of England; not without Brian Clough. A door opens and PETER TAYLOR walks out in time to hear...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to give you some good advice, Brian Clough. (MO RE) (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No matter how good you think you are, or how clever, or how many fancy new friends you make on the telly, the reality of footballing life is this: the Chairman is the boss, then come the directors, then the secretary, then the fans, then the players, and finally, last of all, bottom-of-the- heap, lowest of the low, the one in the end we can all without, is the bloody manager. LONGSON turns and storms off. TAYLOR looks at CLOUGH..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What have you done now? CLOUGH doesn't answer, and storms off in the opposite direction. TAYLOR is left alone, visibly anxious. 103   EXT. PITCH - BASEBALL GROUND - DAY - (1973)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: watches from the touch-line as the game is in progress. "CRASH", a Leeds PLAYER scythes into a Derby PLAYER. "BEEEP", the referee blows his whistle. CLOUGH and leaps off his bench in fury. Shouting abuse..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a bloody disgrace! You should be in the book for that, Cherry! "BEEEP", the referee blows his whistle. REVIE smiles to himself as a Derby PLAYER is carried off on a stretcher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're an animal. A fucking animal, Hunter! SAM LONGSON watches from the director's box. He closes his eyes. PETER TAYLOR witnesses this.. "CRUNCH", another brutal tackle, another whistle. Another Derby PLAYER hobbles off the pitch. Blood streaming from a cut to his head..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll see you in fucking court, Lorimer! CLOUGH's eyes meet REVIE's eyes along the touchline.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PITCH - BASEBALL GROUND - DAY - (1973)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Afterwards: the LEEDS and DERBY players file off the pitch. BREMNER brushes roughly past CLOUGH... (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good luck in Europe.. CLOUGH turns, `What?" BREMNER, GILES, HUNTER, LORIMER carries on walking down the tunnel. Laughing to themselves.. CLOUGH is joined by TAYLOR and JIMMY GORDON. 105   INT. DERBY DRESSING-ROOM - BASEBALL GROUND - DAY - (1973) 105 Afterwards: the Derby dressing-room looks like the Emergency Room at a hospital.. Casualties. Blood. Stitches. Swellings. At least half-a-dozen PLAYERS are injured. Some on stretchers. CLOUGH stares in horror at the wreckage from the doorway. SAM LONGSON appears beside him. Stares at CLOUGH..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You fucking idiot. LONGSON turns and walks away. CLOUGH turns to survey the carnage in the dressing-room. Like a battlefield. CLOUGH's eyes meet TAYLOR's. 106   ARCHIVE TELEVISION NEWS FOOTAGE                               106 The most important night in Derby's history as the Derby players arrive in Turin to play against mighty Juventus.. 107   INT. CLOUGH HOUSE - NIGHT - (1973)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and the children. Huddled together round the television. Eating supper. Watching the Juventus game on TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's Dad, look! BARBARA and the KIDS watch intently. But JUVENTUS score one goal. Then another. The final whistle. JUVENTUS win 3-1.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pity. BARBARA gets to her feet...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right. Bed time! Everyone clean your teeth! (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait..! Look..! ON TV: CLOUGH is in the tunnel. Speaking to a television REPORTER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Disappointed? Not a bit. My players were heroic out there tonight. Effectively we were playing the Italian champions with a reserve team. That many of our first team are injured... 108   INT. TUNNEL - JUVENTUS - NIGHT                               108 CLOUGH continues. PETER TAYLOR stands beside him, visibly pale, stressed...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...it's what happens if you have a Chairman who authorizes a multi- million pound refurbishment of the director's box and hospitality suites before he pays for a proper squad. Suppose it depends on your priorities. Players or prawn sandwiches? I know which I'd prefer. I know which honest, working class Derby supporters would prefer, too.. A commotion breaks out. TV JOURNALISTS ask questions, sensing a great story. CLOUGH continues answering as, beside him, (unseen by anyone else)... ...TAYLOR is white-faced, holding his chest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 109   INT. DRESSING-ROOM - DAY - (1974)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pouring brandy into a glass. DUNCAN MACKENZIE, JOHN O'HARE, and JOHN MCGOVERN sit in front of him. Visibly uncomfortable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Billy Bremner, Boss. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who else?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Norman Hunter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who else?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eddie Gray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who else?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peter Lorimer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are they saying? This falls to MACKENZIE, who knocks back his drink. Trembling hands. Dutch courage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That you're never here. (a beat) That they're worried about the future. (a beat) That you're just going to fill the place with more Derby players.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that all thing's considered they were all a lot happier under...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Under who? MCGOVERN dries. Cannot find the words..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don Revie? (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: avoid his eyes..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that what they say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Boss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That he's the boss? The Guvnor? The Capi di Tutti Fucking Capi?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Boss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that they miss the bingo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bingo?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the carpet bowls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carpet bloody bowls?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It helps them relax before a game. MCGOVERN and O'HARE stare at one another..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That it, Boss? Can we go now? CLOUGH stares, lost in thought: the three PLAYERS go. The door closes. CLOUGH is left alone. Then he gets up, and in a terrifying flash of rage, picks up his glass and throws it against the wall.. 110   EXT. CAR PARK - DAY - (1974)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: walks out into the car park, then he stops in his tracks when he sees.. JOHNNY GILES, BILLY BREMNER and NORMAN HUNTER (among others), with their GIRLFRIENDS and WIVES and KIDS, being shown brand new cars by a SPONSOR. CLOUGH takes JIMMY GORDON aside..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's all this? (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Club cars. Complimentary for the senior payers. Brand new. CLOUGH sees BREMNER, GILES and HUNTER trying out the sports cars. His smile fades. He walks up to the REP from the CAR FIRM..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice to meet you, pet. Now, you can take your lovely sports cars, and put `em back on your transporter..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you talking about? These are ours!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll have complimentary cars when you deserve a compliment. Right now you don't deserve a complimentary bicycle between you. CLOUGH takes the KEYS and gives them to the REPRESENTATIVE..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Complimentary cars when you're not suspended.. (indicates BREMNER) ...and when you lot start winning some games.. (indicated GILES and
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: CLOUGH goes back to his own car..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I had my way, you'd WALK to the ground and back every game.. CLOUGH gets into his car, and roars out, past glowering BREMNER, glowering GILES, glowering HUNTER, glowering GIRLFRIENDS and WIVES. 111   EXT. CLOUGH HOUSE - NIGHT - (1974)                        111 CLOUGH's car pulls up outside his house in Derby. He closes his eyes. Breathes a private sigh of relief. Home. At last. Safe. Surrounded by people who love him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOUGH HOUSE - NIGHT - (1974)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: walks into his house. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing here? Aren't you supposed to be in that hotel in Leeds?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I couldn't stand it for another night. CLOUGH takes off his coat...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? So you drove all the way? What time will you have to get up in the morning...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Half five. CLOUGH bends down. Kisses his wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You smell nice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do I?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgotten what a woman smells like. BARBARA strokes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not like bloody men. That's for sure. 113   OMITTED                                                        113 114   INT. SONS' BEDROOM - CLOUGH HOUSE - NIGHT - (1974)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks into his SONS' room. The eldest is fast asleep, but the youngest says, `Dad?'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You still awake? You should be asleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell us a joke, Dad? (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A joke? All right. There's this bloke walking about in London, when all of a sudden, the city gets hit by a Russian `A' bomb. Booooooooom. CLOUGH sits down, strokes his son's head..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And all the buildings have fallen down. And all the people are dead. And now this bloke is the only man left in the whole of London. CLOUGH continues stroking his son's hair..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he suddenly feels very, very lonely because there's no one else to talk to. Nobody else but him. CLOUGH's SON falls asleep. CLOUGH doesn't notice..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So he decides that he's had enough, that he can't bear being this lonely, and so he climbs up to the top of the one building still standing. The Post Office Tower. And then he jumps off. And he's falling down, down and down and down, the sixteenth floor, the fifteenth floor, the fourteenth, and that's when he hears the phone ringing... CLOUGH looks down. And gets two unexpected shocks. The first is that his SON is already asleep. The second is, there is a tear running down his own cheek. 115   INT. TUNNEL - ELLAND ROAD - DAY - (1974)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The LEEDS PLAYERS clatter off the pitch. Covered in mud. Walking in silence. No smiles. Heads hung low.. CAPTION: "LEEDS 0 - MANCHESTER CITY 2. LEEDS ARE NOW FOURTH FROM BOTTOM" JIMMY GORDON is waiting for CLOUGH..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Chairman wants to see you. Said it was important. Right away. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: :                                            115 CLOUGH's face: already fearing the worst. 68 116   INT. CORRIDOR OUTSIDE BOARDROOM - DAY - (1974)
direction.name: direction

result.heading: LEEDS ARE NOW FOURTH FROM BOTTOM" JIMMY GORDON

direction.raw_text: walks along the corridor. Past the photographs on the wall. The trophies in the cabinets. The pictures of a smiling DON REVIE - mocking him. CLOUGH shoots his cuffs. Rolls his neck. A boxer on his way to the ring. A gladiator on his way to the circus. He knocks on the door, and walks in. MANNY CUSSINS, SAM BOLTON and a third man. A stranger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About bloody time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where you been? I was about to send out a search party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, Mr. Cussins, I know it's not been the best of starts, but in my defence, there are a couple of things I'd like to say...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Martin Hughes. He runs Mercedes here in the North.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hear that's what you like to drive. A Mercedes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's..what I used to drive at Derby. Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, we can't have Leeds United being outdone by Derby County, can we? So Martin here is going to take you over to his showroom and get you sorted out. They begin to walk to the door. CUSSINS puts his arm round CLOUGH... (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Also we figured if you were sitting in a spanking new car yourself, you might be a little more bloody lenient with your senior players, who've kicked off, as you can imagine - being denied what's rightfully theirs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never come between a footballer and his motor!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Especially not Billy bloody Bremner. CLOUGH smiles nervously, visibly relieved...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that it, then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why? You look white as a ghost, man. CUSSINS tightens his grip again, arm round CLOUGH. Unmistakably intimidating..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did you think we'd asked you up here for? CUSSINS's eyes. CLOUGH's eyes. The air crackling with menace and intent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 117   OMITTED                                                       117 118   INT. HOSPITAL - DAY                                           118 CLOUGH visits PETER TAYLOR in a large, crowded ward of old, infirm, dying people. It's a shock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heart attack, eh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Had it three weeks ago, they reckon. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They ran all kinds of tests. Asked me about my diet and my family history. (MO RE) (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told them the only thing they needed to know was that I share my professional life with Brian Clough. That seemed to satisfy them. CLOUGH manages a smile. Moved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm only half-joking, you know. Have we still got jobs?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have. Longson's tried to put a gagging order on me, of course. (mimics) "Any further utterances in public or appearances in the media by Brian Clough will be met with instant dismissal."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I hope you take notice. And act accordingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you like to hear my contrite reply? CLOUGH pulls out a letter..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Due to the complete breakdown in communication with the chairman, Peter Taylor and I find it is impossible to continue our good work for Derby County. We therefore wish to tender our resignations with immediate effect."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to resign. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction
