direction.raw_text: You were. You were taking over the best bunch of players you'd ever seen. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I fancied winning the league, and winning Europe, and doing it better than you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no way you COULD win it better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But that's the only hope I've got.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I only lost four matches..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I can only lose three.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no, no, no.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And still play attractive, clean football. Without cheating!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See, there he goes again..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listening to you, I am struck that this is not just a business matter for you both. It's more than that. It's personal. Am I right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, we're very different people, Don and I. We have different styles. In football and in life. I'm a warm man. An idealist. I do believe in faeries, and that is my outlook. Don is different. There's a hardness to him. A hardness. Maybe he's not even aware of it. But he's a cold person.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't KNOW me! (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that lack of warmth. That coldness was there. Permeated the club when I arrived.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I totally refute that. The atmosphere at Leeds was like a family. A happy family. You ask any of my players. I signed most of them personally. Knew their backgrounds. Their parents. Their streets. I was a father to them. In that club every morning. Massaging those boys. Did you do that for them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They would never have let me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you try? You didn't even try. I soaped those boys down with my own hands. You just went to Leeds with no thought for the club, no thought for the players. Just on some kind of mad personal vendetta with me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well are you surprised? What else was I going to do?? After what you did...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did I do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon, Don. You know exactly. (MORE) (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 4th March 1968. See? I even remember the date. You came to Derby County, the third round of the FA Cup, and you refused to shake my hand. AUSTIN MITCHELL looks up. The CAMERAMEN look up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never! Matter of principle! I always shake the other manager's hand!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You shook Peter Taylor's hand, and my trainer, Jimmy Gordon's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I probably didn't see you!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, you saw me Don. But considered me beneath you. Looked down on me. And dismissed me. Just like you did every other club and every other manager in the country. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never would I knowingly refuse to shake a colleague's hand. The truth is, I probably just didn't know who you were.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Didn't know who I was!" Pull the other one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the truth. (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you certainly know it NOW. All heads turn. That came out unintentionally loud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, we ALL know it now. (a beat) We know you as the man who's constant outbursts, his defaming of fellow professionals, have brought this game, this beautiful game into disrepute. Who had one of the best jobs in the country, at Derby, and managed to get the sack. Who had one of the best partners in the game, in Peter Taylor, and threw him away. Who was given the greatest gift in British football Leeds United, a team that in ten years hasn't finished outside the top four, and took them to the bottom of the first division. Yes, it's fair to say we all know who you are now. AUSTIN MITCHELL's eyes widen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: gentlemen, we're going to have to leave it there..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, let's see where we are in a year's time, Donald Revie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dear oh dear..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's see where we both are in five!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's it for tonight's show. I'd like to thank Brian Clough and Don Revie for joining me...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Austin. The show wraps up. Theme music starts playing. REVIE removes his microphone, turns and walks out. CLOUGH is left staring, hollow-eyed. Wishing the ground would swallow him up..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOUGH'S MERCEDES - DAY - (1974)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: written on the side of the stadium. CLOUGH's car driver past. 147A   INT. CLOUGH'S MERCEDES - DAY - (1974)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Inside the car: CLOUGH drives, staring at the road ahead. Talk on the radio of CLOUGH's dismissal..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boys? Do you think your old man is a fool?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're wrong. He bloody is. A silence. CLOUGH continues to drive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is the least mature person in this car? Who most needs to bloody grow up? Who's been making a right arse of himself the past few months? The BOYS can't help laughing..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who fancies a trip to the seaside? To see Uncle Pete?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me, and all. CLOUGH's foot hits the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MOTORWAY - DAY - (1974)                                 148 CLOUGH's Mercedes heads `South', and accelerates into the distance. 149   EXT. TAYLOR'S HOUSE - BRIGHTON - DAY - (1974)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is working in the garden. He looks up to see CLOUGH standing in the gate to his house.. TAYLOR looks at CLOUGH. Their eyes meet. A poignant moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They've kicked you out, already?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They have.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So how long was that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forty-four days.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Impressive. TAYLOR strains not to show his satisfaction..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what are you doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't make this difficult for me, Pete...you know why I'm here...and I won't bloody grovel. TAYLOR shrugs, "Please yourself". Turns and starts walking inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right. I'm grovelling. I'm on my knees. TAYLOR turns. Sees CLOUGH on his knees. Begging for forgiveness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: apologize unreservedly for being a twat". (CO NTINU ED)
direction.name: direction
